Award.AwardTitle: 2015 Sustainable Nanotechnology Organization (SNO) Conference; Portland, Oregon; November 8 - 10, 2015

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanotechnology will play a key role in achieving sustainability in the global society. However, nanotechnology must itself be integrated into these solutions in an economically and environmentally sustainable manner, and with full public awareness and acceptance. Many existing nanotechnologies are currently not sustainable due to their dependence on large quantities of energy, water, and solvents, the use of non-renewable resources to develop them, or unwanted environmental impacts. The 2015 Sustainable Nanotechnology Organization (SNO) conference program will address these critical aspects of sustainable nanotechnology. The program will be built around selected important systems including agricultural, environmental. health, and energy systems. The systems focus for the meeting brings together researchers from different disciplines studying fate, effects, lifecycle assessment, and analytical challenges in a particular system (e.g. water) into the same sessions to cross-fertilize ideas between them. This is a different approach from most meetings which have separate sessions on these topics, irrespective of the system of interest. The aim of this organization is to provide researchers in a specific system the tools needed to understand how their work fits into achieving sustainability in the larger integrated system. Additional cross-cutting sessions will include manufacturing and industrial ecology, solid waste and e-waste reduction and recycling, modeling, data management, standardization of methods and data reporting, and legal and regulatory aspects. The conference will also better engage health professionals researching and testing novel nanomedicines. Three forum discussions will be: sustainability, nanoinformatics including data reporting and standardization,

The SNO Conference will draw attention to the role of nanomaterials in achieving integrated systems-level sustainable solutions to society's most pressing problems including natural limited resources, greenhouse gas releases, access to clean water and food, and environmental degradation. Societal issues will be addressed in sessions on Education and Social Systems/Governance. It is anticipated that 250 participants from industry, government, academia, and NGO stakeholders will participate. The conference will attract the leading interdisciplinary scientists and will include at least 30 participants who are junior scholars (doctoral and postdoctoral students), with 20 student travel awards (5 specifically for URM students) available to encourage their participation. Thus, the conference will provide networking opportunities for scientists at different career stages. The two and half day schedule will include a number of forum discussions that will foster interactions between young investigators and more established researchers. The SNO Conference is of particular importance to new investigators as there are few if any similar conferences that address the broad topic of Sustainable Nanotechnology. In addition, scientists from underrepresented groups in science will play key roles in the conference. Specific travel awards are available for these faculty and industry participants. Participants will come from not only the U.S., but around the globe, ensuring a diverse and international expert group to facilitate stimulating discussions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported a highly successful conference on the safe and sustainable development and application of nanomaterials and nanotechnology held November 5-7, 2015 in Portland, Oregon.  Approximately 160 people from academia, industry, government, and NGOs participated in the meeting.  The US and international participants represented a broad range of science and engineering disciplines including agriculture, chemistry, environmental engineering, nanoscience, medicine, education, social science, manufacturing, biology, and ecology.  The overarching goal of the conference was to stimulate debate, discussion, visioning, and collaboration across nanotechnology research communities in the area of sustainable nanotechnology. Specific objectives included i) fostering new collaboration among all stakeholders: academia, industry, and regulators for a better understanding of the opportunities for sustainable development of nanotechnology solutions to important societal problems; and ii) advance STEM research and provide opportunities for STEM students to share research ideas, and meet and interact with mentors from academia, industry, and regulators. The meeting also included a 1-day workshop on the measurement, reporting, and sharing of the zeta potential measurements for engineered nanomaterials.

Intellectual merit: The nanoscience and engineering research and education discussed at the meeting has helped to promote the safe and sustainable introduction of nanotechnologies into commerce.  Advances in the use of nanomaterials for sustainable agriculture, improved methods for nanomanufacturing, the effects and nanomaterials on biological and environmental systems, managing nanomaterial waste streams, improving STEM education and public acceptance of nanomaterials, and nanomedicine applications were shared and discussed. The zeta potential workshop outcomes have led to better reporting of zeta potential measurements, including revision of the OECD test guidelines for measuring and reporting this nanomaterial property.

Broader impacts:  The ideas shared at the meeting will help promote the safe and sustainable implementation of nanomaterials and nanotechnology. The "systems" organization of the meeting moved the research community towards technologies that provide system-wide sustainable solutions to some of the most pressing issues facing society including delivering food, energy, and water more sustainably. The SNO meeting provided an opportunity for ~100 students and post docs to present and discuss their research in an open forum, and to meet and discuss their work with senior faculty in their discipline and across disciplines. This close interaction and feedback on their research helps to promote better STEM science, and encourages these students to remain engaged in STEM disciplines. The meeting also promoted interactions between junior faculty members and more senior faculty members, providing opportunities for mentoring and new collaborations.  The zeta potential workshop provided guidance on the collection and reporting of nanomaterial properties and associated metadata in a manner that can be readily shared with the scientific community. It is building the nanoinformatics infrastructure needed for read-across between materials and for efficient data sharing.
